comments.body:
File path:
```
princeton-5/dspace-jspui/src/main/webapp/layout/navbar-default.jsp
```

Decision log:
* use of `target=_blank`
* not deleting existing about and help html, only changing the links
* There are links to help text across dspace (via the question marks in circles, usually linking to a particular section of the help text). I'm  doing the main one just for now

comments.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/37461104/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/37461104)

Coverage increased (+0.08%) to 82.422% when pulling **010fd420fc56c8f03fe40a4b5770945d89d0fc79 on issue_925_feb23** into **567d9d76d4b060f85b44e0e79eb2c4d4559972e6 on alma**.

@hackartisan Thanks for all the feedback and working around the nuances. 

I added a test for the actual record enrichment in `marc_record.rb` -- This should be the last review (famous last words)...

Coverage decreased (-1.5%) to 82.422% when pulling **414eb8d28fb49fd77c827bc3f8151a067cd11de2 on alma** into **f6627a2b1169dc639b8918699183d30e589a1c07 on main**.

marc_liberation.title: New export type: all records with OCLC numbers

comments.body:
My initial shell script (via marcli) took 51 minutes to process all the MARC files and produce new ones.

If I parallelize the work with 4 concurrent `marcli` processes via Linux's native `wait and &` the times comes down to around 23-28 minutes ([see shell script](https://gist.github.com/hectorcorrea/e1e40a312ce93c1ac5d2ec0be5502373#file-pod_parallel-sh)). 

I'll try to run the Ruby and Java versions that @escowles posted and see what the performance looks like.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/37459081/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/37459081)

Coverage decreased (-0.02%) to 82.321% when pulling **333c610b05c5f61dbc188e056afcdb2dee10064d on 1084-courses** into **567d9d76d4b060f85b44e0e79eb2c4d4559972e6 on alma**.

Suggest A Correction email redirects
Collection level storage note should display on component pages.
Collection tabs at the top of each component should navigate to the collection page and switch to that tab.
2 different collection overview pages showing based on how you search

comments.body: @faithc I feel like the storage note should be displaying at the component level too. If a researcher gets to a component via a keyword they are not going to know it might not be onsite.

@ccleeton Yes, the collection-level storage note should display with child components as well like it does now. The note also indicates at which location/library materials are stored/accessible; this should continue to display in pulfalight as well. Ex.
https://findingaids.princeton.edu/collections/C1596/c6 vs. https://findingaids-beta.princeton.edu/catalog/C1596_c6.
Closing this and opening #701 instead.

pulfalight.title: Add message + link to Suggest a Correction form
Statement on Archival Language links

comments.body:
@sdellis Not sure if you saw my response in slack. Moving the FAQs to libanswers works for me. And agree to spelling out AV. I changed the SC website to remove the  / between the words. 
I would be fine to copy the brief statement into the finding aids. Is it possible to do that only in collections where AV is known? @faithc Thoughts?

I think @sdellis is asking about the site, not specific finding aids? (ADAPT is planning to replace current AV notes in finding aids with a boilerplate note (once we get the language from public svs) and link to the statement/policy from there.)
@faithc the Statement on Audiovisual Materials seems like something that we might want to include in the Access and Use notes for A.V. collections, right?

We do currently have notes for AV materials in finding aids; however, ADAPT and PS recently agreed to change this approach to only having a brief note, something like "see SC's policy on..." with a link out to the statement/policy so that when the policy is revised, which often happens, we're not having to change the finding aid notes.

pulfalight.title: Adds About Archival Collections to footer
Upgrade rails to address security vulnerability
Improve discoverability of names and attached metadata for finding linked resources.
Collections merging in call slip when the box number and component is same

comments.body:
This is another example that Annalee and Rosalba experienced
https://findingaids-beta.princeton.edu/catalog/C0035_c021 and https://findingaids-beta.princeton.edu/catalog/C0230_c021

It is also adding all of the info to the call slip. 2 barcodes, all that info in the notes field.
[tn 291225.docx](https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/files/6043624/tn.291225.docx)
Oof. Yeah I just copied all the merging fields to pass to Aeon from PULFA2, but it wouldn't be a problem there because you can't request cross-collection. I'll take a look.

pulfalight.title: Group by a unique identifier for requests.

comments.body: Awesome - glad the blog post was useful!

pulfalight.title: Change image on front page

comments.body: I'm pretty surprised this passes the accessibility tests. Seems like we need some way to better see the title text. Maybe a darkened opacity on the image? Any suggestions @sdellis?
Good point. I'll try adding some opacity to the image.

Here it is with an opacity of .3 on the image, and I swapped the h1 color to be $black-pul. 

![Screen Shot 2021-02-25 at 3 32 02 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65608/109213539-b9b28080-777e-11eb-98a3-e968872d1a65.png)
I like this with the opacity!
I find it pretty hard to read the text with so much going on behind it, but I have no good suggestions for how to improve that. It might just be a personal problem too.
@tpendragon I think that darkening the image, keeping the white lettering, and adding a drop shadow should do the trick. I'm happy to give it a try if it helps.
@sdellis Would you please give that a shot? It sounds like your UI skills vastly exceed mine. Thank you!
